block.p: British Official in Athens Is Assassinated in Street Britain's senior military representative in Greece, Brig. Stephen Saunders, was gunned down just days after a report prepared for Congress recommended sanctions against Greece, describing it as ''passive in response to terrorist activities.'' The Greek police said two gunmen fired from a motorcycle.

Stephen Saunders, was gunned down just days after a report prepared for Congress recommended sanctions against Greece, describing it as ''passive in response to terrorist activities.'' The Greek police said two gunmen fired from a motorcycle.

Rising War Deaths in Congo The International Rescue Committee in New York said two years of war had caused the deaths of more than 1.7 million people in eastern Congo, far more than would be expected under normal conditions.

Reassurances on Sierra Leone The British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, arrived in Freetown to offer assurances of Britain's long-term commitment to its former West African colony, even as British troops prepared to withdraw next week.

Putin to Visit North Korea Russian officials told a Russian newspaper that President Vladimir V. Putin planned to visit North Korea next month, a move that would underscore his active foreign policy and seemed calculated to counter the Clinton administration's plan for a national missile defense.
Mr. Putin moved to put Chechnya under his direct rule, apparently intending to assert the Kremlin's power even as rebels step up attacks.
Service for Japan Leader Thousands of mourners, including President Clinton, attended a state service in Tokyo for the late Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, who died on May 14, six weeks after a stroke.

Panama Drug Traffic Still High A United States Customs intelligence report said that the Panamanian government made little progress this year in fighting drug trafficking and money laundering and that Panama was a transshipment point for cocaine and heroin.

Senate Backs Campaign Bill But Not H.M.O. Measure The Senate voted to require the tax-exempt groups that now secretly raise and spend unlimited sums on political activities to disclose their contributors and spending. But senators rejected a bill to overhaul the nation's managed care system.

Gore to Focus on Medicare Vice President Al Gore said he would deliver a speech in New York City next week on preserving Medicare, as his campaign began promoting a theme of guiding the nation during an era of budget surpluses.
Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic fund-raiser, agreed to serve as chairman of the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles, at the behest of Mr. Gore.

No Copies of Missing E-Mail The White House informed a House committee that it could not find back-up records for lost e-mail messages sent to or from Vice President Al Gore's office in 1998 and 1999.

Bush Proposal on Budgets Gov. George W. Bush proposed an overhaul of the federal budget process to force earlier negotiations and avoid the annual standoffs between Congress and the president over tax policy and spending.

Officer's Transfer Opposed Some members of Congress and gay rights advocates criticized the reassignment to the Pentagon of the commander of Fort Campbell, Ky., where a gay soldier was beaten to death last year and an Army investigation is still under way.
Gay Pride Rally at C.I.A. Representative Barney Frank gave a keynote speech at a gay pride celebration at the Central Intelligence Agency for employees of the C.I.A. and National Security Agency.

Inmate Assails Executioners Bennie Demps, who was convicted of three murders, complained at his execution in Florida that officials had mishandled preparations for the lethal injection and that he ''was in a lot of pain.'' His lawyer demanded a formal investigation. State officials denied any mishandling.

Accord Reached in Albany On Nassau County Bailout Governor Pataki and the Legislature agreed to spend $105 million to bail out Nassau County and impose state oversight of county spending, in an effort to avert financial collapse.

Studio Neighbors' Complaint Lawyers for the upscale Sherry-Netherland Hotel asked a court to ban outdoor concerts and amplifiers associated with the CBS morning program ''The Early Show,'' which the residents find disruptive.

Ruling on Foster-Parent Rights A federal appeals court struck a lower-court ruling that had given some foster parents the same rights as birth parents in cases involving removals of children from homes.

Flaw Seen in Missile Tests Critics of the Clinton administration's antimissile plan and some military experts say tests of the proposed $60 billion system have been rigged to hide its inability distinguish incoming warheads from decoys.
E.P.A. Limits Insecticide Chlorpyrifos, a common ingredient in home, lawn and garden bug killers, poses a health risk and its manufacture for those uses will be stopped by the end of the year.
Stars Stay Alive Dallas beat the New Jersey Devils, 1-0, in the third overtime of Game 5 of the Stanley Cup finals.
Jeff MacNelly The editorial cartoonist who won three Pulitzer Prizes and created the comic strip ''Shoe'' was 52.
Same-Sex Benefits Offered G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler division said that they would begin offering medical, dental and prescription benefits for same-sex partners of their workers.

Shake-Up at Consumer Giant Durk I. Jager resigned as chief executive of Procter & Gamble, which said it would sustain another disappointing quarter; its stock price fell to less than half of what it was worth just four months ago. Alan G. Lafley succeeds Mr. Jager.
Praise for Microsoft Judge Legal experts gave the judge in the Microsoft case high marks, saying he took some risks but grounded his ruling in fundamental principles governing fair competition.

'Survivor' Ratings Soar The CBS show, which chronicles the experiences of 16 people on an island off Borneo, scored extraordinary ratings in its second week, even drubbing ABC's ''Who Wants To Be A Millionaire.''
Editorials: A vote against secret spending; double talk on phone rates; bankruptcy law and violence; attacking hate crimes. Columns: Gail Collins, Thomas L. Friedman.
